line_1: Because the fool would fain be thought a bite.
line_2: Next morn disowns the losses of the night,

line_1: LET Dogs delight to bark and bite;
line_2: Let Bears and Lions growl and fight,

line_1: Thus aids the Foe, and tries the fruitless Bite.
line_2: Th' imprudent Lamprey, urg'd by fierce Despite,

line_1: Sirrah, 'tis me you dare not bite.
line_2: While on my dog you vent your spite;

line_1: E'er said of me, is, I can bite:
line_2: The worst that Envy, or that Spite

line_1: That Shrub was qualify'd to Bite;
That Shrub was qualify'd to Bite;
line_2: Had bid his Gard'ner rid it quite,

line_1: And opening wide thy beak to bite.
Bear stronger venom in their bite.
And give his Horse a Bite;
It is the Slaver kills, and not the Bite.
line_2: Of all mad Creatures, if the Learn'd are right,

line_1: In mumbling of the Game they dare not bite.
The creature is so sure to kick and bite,
line_2: A muleteer's the man to set him right.

line_1: Would whisper to himself; A Bite,
line_2: And, (like a Wag) sat down to Write,

line_1: Their most obliging friends they bite,
line_2: Now warm with malice, envy, spite,

line_1: Too big to swallow, and too hard to bite.
line_2: Or in the hog-trough rests in perfect spite,

line_1: As babes that mumble coral, cannot bite,
line_2: Dull criticks on best bards pour harmless spite,

line_1: But soon the venom of his mortal bite
line_2: His face grew pale, his strength forsook him quite,
